title: How to Remove Hair Dye from Your Scalp

steps.title: Rub baby oil around your hairline and ears before you dye your hair.
steps.content: Rub baby oil around your hairline and ears before you dye your hair. Pour about 1 tsp (4.9 mL) of baby oil in the palm of your hand. Then, dip your fingers into the baby oil and rub it along your hairline and around your ears [1] X Expert Source Gina Almona Professional Hair Stylist Expert Interview. 12 February 2021. . The baby oil will create a slick surface for the hair dye and will deter it from fully soaking into your skin. [2] X Research source Just make sure not to get any of the baby oil in your hair; otherwise, the hair dye might not be able to penetrate the baby oil to reach your hair. Instead of baby oil, you can use petroleum jelly or coconut oil as well. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Avoid showering before dyeing your hair to build up natural oils.
steps.content: Avoid showering before dyeing your hair to build up natural oils. Keep your skin naturally moisturized by refraining from showering or washing your face prior to dyeing your hair. The buildup of oils around your hairline will act as a barrier to the hair dye and keep it from soaking into your skin. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Wear a protective headband to keep the dye from dripping down your scalp.
steps.content: Wear a protective headband to keep the dye from dripping down your scalp. Put on a thin, elastic headband before you begin. Keep the headband just beyond your hairline so it does not interfere with dyeing your hair. [5] X Research source Also, consider placing an old, thin towel around your neck to keep the dye from running down your neck behind your head. If you have a hairdresser’s cape, then put this on over the towel to protect your clothing from the dye as well.

steps.title: Apply leftover hair dye to the stained areas using a cotton swab.
steps.content: Apply leftover hair dye to the stained areas using a cotton swab. Be careful not to coat clean areas of your skin, and to only apply the hair dye to the stain. This will cause the chemicals within the hair dye to reactive and will make it easier to remove the original stain. [6] X Research source Just be careful not to get any of the hair dye in your eyes. Consider wearing goggles to protect your eyes and the sensitive skin around your eyes.

steps.title: Rub the hair dye into the stain with a cotton swab for 30-60 seconds.
steps.content: Rub the hair dye into the stain with a cotton swab for 30-60 seconds. Use gentle, circular motions to rub the hair dye into the stained area. Only rub within the perimeter of the stain to avoid spreading the hair dye to other portions of your skin. [7] X Research source If the hair dye begins to irritate your skin, stop rubbing the area immediately and rinse your face with water.

steps.title: Use an exfoliating soap and a wet washcloth to rinse the dye off your skin.
steps.content: Use an exfoliating soap and a wet washcloth to rinse the dye off your skin. Apply a pea-sized amount of your exfoliating soap to a wet washcloth. Gently wipe away the reactivated hair dye from your skin. [8] X Research source If you do not have an exfoliating soap, use your normal face soap instead. Repeat the process as needed to further lighten and remove the hair dye stain.

steps.title: Apply a pea-sized amount of toothpaste to the stain using a cotton swab.
steps.content: Apply a pea-sized amount of toothpaste to the stain using a cotton swab. Use a non-gel toothpaste that has baking soda in it. Distribute the toothpaste along the entirety of the stain. Discard any excess toothpaste using a tissue. [9] X Research source If you have an old, soft-bristled toothbrush, you can use that to scrub the stained area instead. Just be careful when using a toothbrush, as the bulky head might make it harder to handle precisely. [10] X Research source Instead of toothpaste, try using a cotton swab dipped in vinegar or hairspray. The process for all three alternatives is the same, and each will act as an exfoliant to lift the hair dye from your skin. Just be careful not to get any of these products in your eyes. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Use the cotton swab to rub the toothpaste into the stain for 1 minute.
steps.content: Use the cotton swab to rub the toothpaste into the stain for 1 minute. Apply a gentle pressure with the cotton swab to avoid irritating your skin with the toothpaste. If the cotton swab does not seem to be exfoliating your skin properly, put on a pair of gloves and rub the toothpaste using your finger. [12] X Research source The gritty texture of the toothpaste, along with the reactive power of the baking soda, will lift the hair dye from your pores.

steps.title: Wipe away the toothpaste and lifted hair dye with a wet washcloth.
steps.content: Wipe away the toothpaste and lifted hair dye with a wet washcloth. Use an old washcloth that you don’t mind getting hair dye stains on, and wipe your skin clean. If the stains are completely removed, follow up by washing your face properly with soap and water. [13] X Research source Repeat the process if needed, but make sure not to repeat the process too many times that you irritate your skin.

steps.title: Apply makeup remover to the stained area using a cotton swab.
steps.content: Apply makeup remover to the stained area using a cotton swab. Use a dense or creamy makeup remover, like cold cream, that will be able to rest on your skin. Completely coat all of the stained areas around your scalp and hairline. [14] X Research source You can use liquid makeup removers like micellar water, but they may not be as effective.

steps.title: Use the cotton swab to rub the stained areas on your skin for 1 minute.
steps.content: Use the cotton swab to rub the stained areas on your skin for 1 minute. Use circular motions to work the makeup remover into your pores. Apply gentle pressure when doing this to avoid irritating your skin.

steps.title: Allow the makeup remover to soak into your skin for 5 minutes.
steps.content: Allow the makeup remover to soak into your skin for 5 minutes. The makeup remover will help break down the pigments in the hair dye and remove the stain from your skin. Avoid letting the makeup remover soak longer than 5 minutes as it may cause skin irritation when mixed with the hair dye. [15] X Research source If the makeup remover starts to irritate your skin at any point during the soaking process, wipe it off immediately and wash your face.

steps.title: Wipe away the makeup remover with a damp washcloth and rinse your face.
steps.content: Wipe away the makeup remover with a damp washcloth and rinse your face. Gently wipe the makeup remover off, and be careful not to spread it across your face near your eyes. The makeup remover will have remnants of the hair dye in it that you do not want to come in contact with your eyes. [16] X Research source Repeat the process to further remove the hair dye stain as needed.

steps.title: Use a cotton swab or a gloved finger to rub baby oil onto the stain.
steps.content: Use a cotton swab or a gloved finger to rub baby oil onto the stain. Pour 1 tsp (4.9 mL) of baby oil or a similar light oil, such as coconut oil, into the palm of your hand. Dip the cotton swab or your gloved finger into the baby oil and use circular motions to rub the oil onto the stain. [17] X Research source Treat the stains before you go to bed to allow the baby oil to soak in your skin overnight.

steps.title: Allow the baby oil to soak the stain overnight so the color breaks down fully.
steps.content: Allow the baby oil to soak the stain overnight so the color breaks down fully. Avoid washing or touching your face while the baby oil is soaking into your skin. Sleep on your back to keep it from rubbing off while you sleep. [18] X Research source Cover your pillow with an old towel to keep the baby oil from staining the fabric. Make sure the towel is one you don’t mind ruining since the oil will stain it.

steps.title: Wash your face in the morning with warm water and soap to remove the oil.
steps.content: Wash your face in the morning with warm water and soap to remove the oil. Wash your face as you normally would with soap. Avoid using an exfoliating scrubber, as your skin might be irritated from the hair dye. [19] X Research source Repeat the process the following night if needed.
